newsitem.title: USA: Lilly Q3 gross margin off vs yr-ago level.
newsitem.headline: Lilly Q3 gross margin off vs yr-ago level.

text.p: Eli Lilly & Co said its gross profit margin for the third quarter was 72.1 percent, off from 74.3 percent in the year-ago period.
The drugmaker's concern about the lower margin is "not very high," said chief financial officer Charles Golden.
Last year's gross margin was boosted by a product mix dominated by high-margin products, such as Prozac, he said.
"Now you see a more diverse product portfolio," Golden said in a conference call with reporters after the company's release of third quarter financial results.
Shares in Lilly were up 1-3/8 to 70-1/8.

In addition, he said, increasing sales of lower-margin drugs such as ReoPro and higher sales at the company's PCS Health Systems unit, which "tends to have a dampening effect on our gross margin," Golden said.
Of the 2.2-point gross margin decline, PCS accounted for about a percentage point, he said.
"That doesn't really concern us because that just shows that PCS is growing, quite frankly," Golden said.
He said the third-quarter margin was boosted by some productivity improvements at Lilly plants.
"Over the next several quarters we should really see that gross margin go up," he said, declining to quantify Lilly's expectations for margin improvement.

"If you think about what's happening to the mix of our products ... as Zyprexa gets into the market and we see sales improve on that, that's a relatively high-margin product. Some things like that would indicate to us that our gross margin ought to be going up in the future," he said.
Separately, he added, foreign-exchange translations reduced Lilly third-quarter worldwide sales by about two percent, and price pressures reduced it by about one percent.
Quarterly sales were $1.8 billion, up from $1.63 billion in the year-ago period.
